prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 6 continuum emission of H-[4.5]>4 sources in COSMOS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
The aim of this science goal is detecting the cold dust continuum emission of 18 H-[4.5]>4 galaxies in COSMOS, with the ALMA Band 6.
Observations are requested using 'AggregateBandWidth' with the desired continuum sensitivities, so the obtained observing times are optimised for continuum detection.
The redshifts of all sources have been set to 0 simply to make the AOT use the same sky frequency window for all targets.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We only need continuum detection, so we chose 'AggregateBandWidth'.

The chosen angular resolution (1.2 arcsec) is intermediate between the angular resolution of our Spitzer IRAC and ground-based H-band data for our targets. With this chosen angular resolution and a S/N>10, we will have an astrometric accuracy < 0.1 arcsec (assuming dtheta~0.6 x FWHM/(S/N)).
For target detection, we only need a maximum angular scale of 3 arcsec (max. size of our targets).

In this proposal, we only aim at detecting the cold dust continuum emission of our targets, and the requested sensitivity corresponds to this purpose.
We chose Band 6 because it offers the best compromise between detectability for our targets and not being very restricted for weather conditions. All our targets are dust-obscured sources at high z, so they are expected to be relatively bright at 1.1 mm.
We aim at determining which of our targets are ULIRGs, i.e. have SFR> 150 Msun/yr. At z~3-5, this corresponds to S_nu(1.1mm)>0.5 mJy. To detect all sources with such fluxes with >10 sigma confidence, we request a sensitivity of r.m.s.=0.05 mJy at 1.1 mm.
The observing times have been computed using 'AggregateBandWidth', optimised for continuum detection.

There are none non-standard choices.
We chose Band 6 because it is quite unsensitive to weather conditions, and our targets are dusty sources at high z, so they are expected to be relatively bright in Band 6.
We chose the upper frequency part of this Band, where our targets are expected to be brightest, and still the atmospheric transmission is high.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 3.8 h of ALMA Band 6 to detect the dust continuum emission of 18 bright Spitzer/IRAC galaxies at z~4 that are extremely faint at lambda < 1.6 micron, with colours H-[4.5]>4. These extreme colours and redshifts are very similar to those of the seemingly rare sub-millimetre source GN10 at z=4.04. However, only ALMA can prove which of our sources are extreme starbursts like GN10, or simply ULIRGs at z~4. Our main goals are: 1) detect all ULIRGs in our sample using ALMA Band 6, and determine which of them are extreme starbursts like GN10, in order to assess whether GN10-like sources are more common than previously thought; 2) estimate the obscured star formation rates (SFR) of our targets, and derive their contribution to the total SFR density at z~4; 3) analyse the 24 micron/Band 6 flux excess for the 24 micron-detected sources to weigh the contribution of an AGN component to the overall dust emission. This high-impact proposal will demonstrate the power of ALMA to reveal a new population of massive, dusty star-forming galaxies at z~4 that are at the detection limit of the deepest near-IR surveys.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: Another proposal with overlapping investigators (PI Ikarashi) will target ALMA sources that are also red, but they are significantly fainter in Spitzer/IRAC than our current targets, and are expected to lie at higher redshifts (z~6).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
